title: English natives,don't suck at speaking your language
body:
Seems this mistake is made by english natives(and americans) ,which is quite  irking.

"Should have been"/"would have been" can  be written as should've been,would've been.

"Should of"/"would of" have NO MEANING,it's just people pronouncing should've /would've which sounds like should of/would of.

replies.body:
Fun fact:
The average American (US) speaks 0.8 languages.
Not true, we have several languages. American, English, Texan, Californian, New York, etc
I really don't get how texan is it's own language.
You clearly never met a Texan
I AM TEXAN.
The point still stands.
...the point is he said I've never met a texan when i am a texan.
I said he never, sorry we're speaking English not Texan so I can see where the confusion came from.
Y'all be shootin dem tin folk ten times high yeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee hawwwwwwwwwwww
You ever see a native Texan speak American though? Doesn't happen

Not so fun fact:
I got a reduced score in Oral English at school, because I had an American accent (non-native speaker), and she said so in class, likely so most heard it.
_I've not wanted to speak english ever since._

Nowhere did it say we were supposed to learn _British_, which makes me conclude our teacher didn't think American was counting as English.
I said I watched a lot of movies, and that most movies are American, but that was no excuse.

Don't suck at punctuations...

>been,would've been.

>NO MEANING,it's just 

>English natives,don't suck at speaking your language

Like spaces after the comma. Oh, and you're saying that north americans aren't native english speakers? "English natives(and americans)" 

Aside from that, anybody who has played on the EUW servers knows the struggle of communicating with that fellow teammate who seemed to skip english class.
You have english class where you come from?
Out here in the united america of state, we ain't got nothin like that nonsense.
LOL

>_Make sure not to support Trump if you want the same for **ur** children_

"ur" or "your"? :O

_...Please tell me that was a deliberate mistake._
League of Grammar
wow thanks for your English lesson on a board for a video game what would we do without you?
work for McDonald

I know right? IT'S SO TRIGGERING TO SEE IT EVERYWHERE AND I'M NOT EVEN BRITISH/AMERICAN, I AM GREEK, MY NATIVE LANGUAGE IS COMPLETELY DIFFERENT!!! If i'm triggered so much with that shit, Natively English speakers should have their eyes bleed when they see it.

Same; I'm German and yet my English skills are better than most of the native English League community...

...or random website comments...

The focus is different when one is learning English as a secondary language vs a native speaker.  Grammar school does not actually delve into the intricacies of the English language, and by the time students reach high school, the focus is split between grammar and literature. Consequently, the grading is scaled toward understanding literature, and language structure is not reinforced.


Recall, neither England nor America has something akin to L'Academie de Francais and as such, the language is just not enforced. I will admit that I am not aware of the standards of other countries such as Greece, but I'd imagine the complexity of English combined with the lack of societal reinforcement is to blame.

Well, Being Greek, the only language i can't seem to learn even if i tried is German. I have no idea about Asian languages, they seem way too complex. But English? I have never studied english for more than 10 minutes at a time, let alone finding it complex. English is so easy, i can't understand why others i know struggled to even get an ECCE degree or something. Although i have to admit, my accent is terrible, probbably because i never speak English, i just read, listen and write, and you can't improve your accent unless you speak it.
I agree. I will never understand why people say English is one of the hardest languages in the world, like no, English is one of the EASIEST.

Foreign speakers tend to learn a different language through readin/writing before speaking/listening. This makes them very aware of correct spelling and grammar, but have poor accents and difficulties with the actual spoken language (slang, speed, slurring of certain words, etc).

Native speakers, on the other hand, learn to speak the language before learning to read and write. Thus, spelling tends to be more difficult, as well as some parts of grammar, since speaking is more deeply ingrained (for English, especially, spelling is inconsistent, due to the many, many languages it is composed of).

For example, I learned Spanish as a second language. Spelling is ridiculously easy for me - if I hear a word in Spanish, I can spell it without having to think about it, even if I've never heard it before. Native Spanish speakers often can't, though. It's the same in every language - foreigners tend to have a better grasp on the written language than the natives.
Well, i don't know about other educational systems but here in Greece, we studied Grammar and spelling a lot and it was important in school.

As you pointed out it's a sounding out issue and I agree it  should be avoided, However,  I'm not sure if it's up to us to point it out. 

I avoid, could and should have, because it seems passive.

I think 2, In the example below is better, but that's only my opinion.

Example: 

1. I should have skipped reading the post, I could have, but I did not.

2. I will not read the next grammar police post.

Well,i'm not a native english speaker. I think  it's a mistake made only by the native speaker because for now, I didn't see this mistake for non native. I know it's because the language is heard before being written for native while it's the opposite for non native.

I find this to be true with most languages, not just English. Native speakers of most languages adopt a slang that is not considered proper (insert language here). 

Since most non-native speakers learn through academic means, they learn the proper words, grammar, sentence structure, and syntax. A lot of people online (myself included) type how we would actually speak. This does not mean we do not understand proper words, although that is definitely the case for some people.
You didn't have to add (Insert Language Here) to make your sentence complete; doesn't change the meaning at all. Good writing miniizes redundancy except where it has benifits.

its/it's
their/they're/there

I agree, it's very frustrating. My personal pet peeve is when someone says "hence why" in a discussion. 

"I got tired of mowing my lawn, hence why I bought a goat." Should either be written as, "hence I bought the goat" or "that's why I bought the goat".

Use hence, or why. Not both.
Damn, I didn't know that. I'm actually really grateful that you pointed that out lol.

As a former grammar nazi, I would offer you this piece of advise. Don't judge people for how they speak, or write. Even if it is wrong.

Think of it as character acting, would you yell at an actor on stage for speaking english poorly for their role in a performance? I should hope not.

Treat others the same way, don't force them to break character for your sake, it's not your place to tell them they are wrong or should change.

Perspective means a lot, I hope this helps.

Why would it be a bad think to correct people as long as they learn something? I think it's better that they learn this in an environment  where a mistake has no consequences. I don't care If i'm corrected , the bitter more it is, the faster your learn,the longer you remember.
I don't understand why people are triggered when they're corrected.This is when ignorance becomes a choice, which is worst than hurting your feelings because you're spitting on people that can't afford a proper education.
I'm not forcing someone to change their philosophy of life ,i'm just correcting a grammar mistake....

Because it's presumptuous. 

Who are you (and when I say that I mean the figurative, hypothetical, "you" and not you personally) to tell someone that they are wrong? Who are you to say, "You cannot/should not speak this way!" Who are you to undermine the will of another? It's not your place to correct someone for their speech. If someone wishes to improve on their linguistic ability, they will actively seek out the required learning on their own.

Let's go back to the analogy I made in my initial post, character acting. If an actor is PURPOSEFULLY speaking in an improper manner in order to better emulate a certain type of person, you would not correct them. So why then would you treat an actual person in such a manner? If anything, THAT is spitting on their perceived level of education. 

Now let's use another example: I am an african american male, as I am sure you are more than aware, in the United States the stereotypical "black/ghetto" community does not speak proper english, it's practically it's own dialect of english. I myself was raised to speak the language properly, and pride myself in doing so, but I would NEVER walk up to a fellow african american and tell them that their speech is improper, because it isn't, it's simply how they speak. I did not go to a special school, same public school as them, same underpaid teachers, same poor family background, etc. I simply had the gift for articulation in a way that my peers didn't. 

For many, language and patterns of speech are learned not from school, but from family, via mimicry. You learn how to speak from your parents, it is a part of your identity, cultural or otherwise. Then a teacher comes along and teaches you the fine print of language in school, you either adapt or you don't, and either is fine. It has nothing to do with intelligence, for many people speaking in a certain way is comfortable to them.

THAT is why it's rude to correct another's speech. THAT is why people get "triggered", because you aren't just correcting them, you are attacking their identity, you are placing yourself ABOVE THEM and saying, "The way you speak is wrong." You have no right to do so. You are not better than they are, and unwanted constructive criticism is incredibly rude. 

What you are implying when you say "I don't care if I'm corrected, the more bitter it is, the faster you learn, the longer you remember." is nothing short of glorifying shame culture.  

It has nothing to do with ignorance, nor lack of education, and everything to do with identity. "Live and let live"
You are but a single amoeba in a larger organism, don't go making the other amoeba sick. Don't shame the zebra because you don't like his stripes. 

Do you understand?
Curious, what made you stop?

I came to the realizations that I outlined during my exchange with the OP.

I was being an jerk and lording my linguistic ability over my peers, I never stopped to consider that the way others spoke could be okay even if it wasn't perfect. I strive towards self-development in everything I do, and so I decided that correcting the speech of others was a habit that was not serving me or anyone else, and so I needed to let it go.

Also I worked in a theme park for a year with a a lot of foreign visitors who were sensitive about their English skills, and that experience broadened my perspective.  

So I came up with the "character acting" analogy, and that made it easier to switch the urge to correct others off.

You should of thought about that before coming here REEEEEE
_beats chest_

There's another grammar mistake that I see a lot that really annoys me, but for some reason I doubt that anyone else even knows about it:

"Yay" is not a word.  "Yea" is pronounced how you would sound out "yay."  "Yea" is not pronounced, nor is it short for, "yeah."

EDIT:  Honestly tho, I don't care as much as it might sound.  I just saw a post about grammar and had to vent.  Sorry for coming off so aggressive.
yay is a word though.

Agreed. "Yay or nay" (yes or no), if I remember correctly.
A bit old-fashioned words I think, but to my knowledge, accepted in everyday speech nonetheness.
No, "yay"is like hooray. "yes or no" is "yea or nay"

I thought the hooray was "yey" (though as slang), as yes was "yay". Well, I claim ignorance on that one. Neither are words I use...barely ever.

But one learn something new every day.
https://english.stackexchange.com/questions/817/is-yay-or-nay-an-acceptable-alternative-to-yea-or-nay

In all honesty, who cares? It's a game. No one gives two craps about your grammar as long as you made yourself understood. English is a shitty language that's only convenient as far as communication goes.
I'd rather speak English than a myriad of other languages.
I really hope this is a joke...
Why would it be?
Because English is basically a myriad of many differeny European languages in it's own right.
